image.altText: Federal shadow minister for Indigenous Australians Jacinta Price standing and speaking outside a voting centre.

props.synopsis: Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price has spoken repeatedly of the "damaging impacts of mass migration" – but the Northern Territory wants to attract thousands more migrants.

title.children: In Jacinta Nampijinpa Price's home territory, officials want more migrants

image.altText: A close shot of Aboriginal woman with black hair, gray streaks, wearing a black and red polo shirt, gentle smile expression.

props.synopsis: A decades-long partnership between Indigenous elders and the Northern Territory’s prison system is helping prisoners reconnect with culture and encouraging them to turn their lives around.

title.children: The senior citizens healing prisoners from inside jailhouse walls

image.altText: An Indigenous woman sits on a walking frame in a gallery space. Colourful ceramic pots are in front of her.

props.synopsis: Between treatments, Purple House patients have been creating colourful works of ceramic art. The results are now on display in Alice Springs.

title.children: Ceramic work of remote dialysis patients on display in Alice Springs

image.altText: Three police officers standing around an Indigenous man in a wheelchair, at community markets.

props.synopsis: Body-worn video footage played to the Darwin Local Court captures a loud thud as an Aboriginal man with a disability is dropped into a police wagon, drawing an audible gasp from another officer.

title.children: NT police officer assaulted Aboriginal man in wheelchair, court rules

image.altText: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price

props.synopsis: The Jacinta Nampijinpa Price saga is a chink in Sussan Ley's armour and at the very least has handed Labor damaging material for their 2028 election campaign.

title.children: A Nampijinpa Price-sized chink in Ley's armour and an Albanese fashion faux pas

image.altText: A big crab pictured tied from his claws to its body by a tight green rope and held

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory's mud crab industry will temporarily shut down after a fisheries assessment found stock numbers had fallen below a "trigger point".

title.children: NT mud crabs off Christmas menu as industry closes for three months

image.altText: A woman smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: A study will work with Indigenous researchers who will map cultural assets and integrate traditional healing to improve outcomes in remote centres.

title.children: Researcher wants First Nations suicide prevention put 'in our hands'

image.altText: Politician looks ahead at press conference

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory chief minister is spending her first overseas trip spruiking the NT's ability to host hundreds of Japanese Self-Defense Force soldiers each year.

title.children: NT leader flies to Japan in bid to draw defence troops to Darwin

image.altText: Peter Mandelson and Keir Starmer walking down a hallway smiling

props.synopsis: After dogging the US president for months, evidence of a connection to Jeffrey Epstein has claimed a senior scalp within the British government.

title.children: How the Jeffrey Epstein saga spread to British politics

image.altText: A close-up shot of Sarah Henderson speaking in Parliament House.

props.synopsis: Liberal senator Sarah Henderson says Jacinta Nampijinpa Price's frontbench sacking was "disappointing". Follow live.

title.children: Liberal senator says Nampijinpa Price's frontbench sacking 'disappointing'

image.altText: An Aldi shopping cart

props.synopsis: Online shopping scams are now one of the most frequently reported scam types and experts say they are alarmingly common, impersonating well-known brands and being promoted in search engine advertisements.

title.children: More Australian consumers are falling for mimic shopping websites

image.altText: An elderly man sips on a drink with a straw in front of more than a dozen cupcakes.

props.synopsis: States and territories will use a health ministers' meeting today to call on the federal government to do more to address what they say is a critical aged care crisis affecting hospitals around the nation.

title.children: 'A tragedy': 2,500 elderly patients stuck in hospital waiting for aged care

image.altText: A close-up of Emmanuel Macron frowning.

props.synopsis: France is stuck in a cycle of political chaos, with no clear end in sight. It has sparked calls for President Emmanuel Macron's resignation and has become so dire that another round of snap legislative elections is considered possible.

title.children: Macron is so unpopular in France, many say resignation is his only option

image.altText: Mariah Carey performs between two black male dancers.

props.synopsis: A lot happened this week. Have you been paying attention?

title.children: Weekly news quiz: A lunar eclipse, the VMAs and a new richest person

image.altText: A woman with short blonde hair smiles, with black and whit images of protesters holding signs reading "our ANU" behind her.

props.synopsis: The announcement of vice-chancellor Genevieve Bell's resignation on Thursday was greeted with cheers, however the view on campus is that this alone will not reverse the erosion of trust and morale that has already occurred.

title.children: Julie Bishop says the ANU is 'turning a page', but many argue it can't with her as chancellor

image.altText: A man in a suit sits on a leather lounge, looking professional.

props.synopsis: Community leaders say the government must consider social and legal reforms to address a spike in Islamophobic incidents.

title.children: Muslim groups welcome Islamophobia report amid harassment spike

image.altText: vogel gfx

props.synopsis: The man in charge of the Northern Territory government's handling of a major methane leak at a Santos gas plant was working with a lobbyist for the project's co-owner.

title.children: Regulator in gas leak 'scandal' had paid role with industry lobbyist

image.altText: Yuval Raphael wearing a black fitted suit with long tassels hanging from arms, arms out, holding mic, singing on stage

props.synopsis: Irish national broadcaster RTE has said Ireland will not participate in Eurovision 2026 if Israel does, citing the ongoing and appalling loss of lives in Gaza.

title.children: Ireland threatens Eurovision boycott if Israel takes part

image.altText: A portrait shot of a smiling woman.

props.synopsis: The acclaimed author's father was a greyhound trainer and her mother ran a TAB. Her unconventional childhood inspired her eighth book, Tenderfoot.

title.children: Toni Jordan grew up at the greyhound track. It inspired her latest novel

image.altText: Dezi Freeman pictured outside a court in Wangaratta.

props.synopsis: A criminology researcher says rewards do work as a way of catching people, even if the success rate appears low.

title.children: Former police say rewards can work as $1m offered in Dezi Freeman search

image.altText: Two plain clothes police officers carrying paper bags.

props.synopsis: Investigators say they've broken up a major drug syndicate operating out of Melbourne's west and north-west, seizing $20 million worth of illegal drugs.

title.children: Police seize 38kg of cocaine in Melbourne drug bust

image.altText: A profile view of a man wearing a black baseball cap and orange hi-vis vest

props.synopsis: The trial for Lamar Ahchee, who is accused of being involved in drug smuggling in Bali, is underway.

title.children: Australian man faces trial in Bali over drug charges that risk death penalty

image.altText: Macaque monkeys grooming.

props.synopsis: The Launceston City Council has agreed to send a group of councillors, senior staff and community members to Japan at an estimated cost of more than $60,000 — but one ratepayer believes it is "nothing more than a junket holiday".

title.children: Council's $60k trip to Japanese city that gifted monkeys questioned

image.altText: A tornado making landfall in a rural area

props.synopsis: The major drenching is unusual for early spring and resulted in Sydney's wettest September day since 1879.

title.children: Tornadoes in NSW not unusual, but September rain heaviest in 146 years

image.altText: Kween G in a red beret, smiling as she handles the lighting equipment inside a live music venue.

props.synopsis: When the Red Rattler theatre in Sydney's inner west installed acoustic foam in the walls behind its stage, it didn't just make the venue soundproof — but future-proof.

title.children: Sydney music venue's 'massive difference' curbs noise complaint fears

image.altText: Man in grey hoodie and grey beanie holds box of groceries

props.synopsis: A year after opening its doors, OzHarvest's first free supermarket in Adelaide says demand for food relief is greater than ever.

title.children: OzHarvest says more people seeking food relief amid cost-of-living pressures

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and tie speaks into a microphone.

props.synopsis: Secretary-General of the OECD and former Coalition finance minister Mathias Cormann suggests Australians keep an open mind to nuclear power, saying there isn't "anything inherently partisan" about the energy source.

title.children: Cormann urges open mind about nuclear power amid climate debate

image.altText: Larry Ellison sitting in a room at the White House

props.synopsis: The switch in the ranking comes after a blockbuster earnings report from Oracle, powered by multi-billion-dollar orders from customers as the AI race heats up.

title.children: Larry Ellison briefly overtakes Elon Musk as world's richest person

image.altText: A child's hands holding a red capsicum wrapped in plastic.

props.synopsis: Industry is cautiously moving ahead with a new soft plastic recycling system in the wake of the REDcycle disaster. How will it work, and can we really have a circular soft plastic system in Australia?

title.children: Soft plastic recycling is slowly returning. Will it work this time?

image.altText: Luke Briggs smiles and holds his dog.

props.synopsis: Two police officers are facing a negligent manslaughter charge following the death of a man several days after his arrest.

title.children: Two Victoria Police officers charged with negligent manslaughter

image.altText: The back of a woman and man at a polling booth.

props.synopsis: Electoral Commission of Queensland data has revealed about 340,000 eligible Queenslanders failed to cast a vote at last year's state election.

title.children: More than $4.5m in fines paid after thousands fail to vote in Queensland

image.altText: Sussan Ley in the House of Representatives.

props.synopsis: Machinations over who will replace Liberal senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price on the Coalition frontbench are already underway, with the party's right warning it would be "incendiary" if the position was handed to someone from the left.

title.children: Senior liberals warn Ley against 'incendiary' frontbench replacement pick

image.altText: Men in military camo with black balaclavas, green headbands and assault rifles stand in a line

props.synopsis: Since October 7, 2023 Hamas has lost its most senior leaders and military organisation, but two years in, it has preserved some capacity to keep fighting Israeli troops and remain the dominant force inside Gaza.

title.children: Israel's goal is to destroy Hamas. Here is what the group has left

image.altText: Gout Gout of Queensland celebrates after winning a track race, yelling and raising his arms wide

props.synopsis: Usain Bolt delivers a simple piece of advice to Gout Gout as the Australian teenage sprint sensation prepares for his first world championships.

title.children: 'It's never just easy': Usain Bolt's message to Gout Gout ahead of world titles debut
